doc.title: Performance
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Korea Weekly Kickstart KOSPI rebounded by 0.5 amid the 2nd Commercial Act amendment and DII inflowsKorea Weekly Kickstar_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: KOSPI rebounded by \(0.5\%\) amid the 2nd Commercial Act amendment and DII inflows. The Securities, Auto and Shipbuilding sectors outperformed this week, while the Utilities, Leisure and Steel sectors underperformed the most (Exhibit 12).
FIIs continued to sell the KOSPI market, driven by inflows for KOSPI Tech & F&B (Exhibit 39).
KOSPI 12m- forward EPS was unchanged this week. The F&B sector saw the strongest upward earnings revisions, while the Pharmaceutical sector was revised down the most this week (Exhibit 26).
The KRW weakened \(0.6\%\) vs. USD this week. Also, it weakened \(0.2\%\) vs. EUR and \(0.5\%\) vs. JPY.
The latest Korea Equity Risk Barometer (GSSRKERB Index) declined to 0.4, staying in risk- neutral territory.

2nd Commercial Act Amendment: On Monday (Aug 25), the ruling coalition, centered on the Democratic Party of Korea, passed a "stronger" second Commercial Act amendment bill in the National Assembly plenary

session, which includes mandatory cumulative voting and expansion of separately elected audit committee members. These provisions were excluded from the earlier Commercial Act revision that passed the national assembly in July after bipartisan disputes. Cumulative voting allows shareholders to allocate multiple votes in proportion to their holdings, thereby increasing the influence of minority investors in electing directors. Passage of this measure - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - a rise in shareholder proposals, particularly those targeting board appointments. In the meantime, Korean companies that expanded shareholder proposals have increased, especially driven by proposals around the appointment of members of the board of directors. Given this backdrop, ordinary shareholders' efforts to influence board composition and decisions will likely continue, improving corporate governance. After passage of the second Commercial Act amendment, the ruling Democratic Party of Korea, accelerating amendments to the Commercial Act for improving corporate governance, is now considering mandatory cancellation of treasury shares.
Weak Seasonality and potential drawdown ahead?

Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
Charts of the week: 2nd Commercial Act Amendment 4
Charts of the week: Weak Seasonality and potential drawdown Ahead? 6
Valuation discount relative to Global and Asia regional peers 15
Currency, rates and commodities 18
Korea ERB, Credit and Market Technicals 19
Disclosure Appendix 20

After falling \(14\%\) during February- April, the KOSPI index has rallied nearly \(40\%\) without any meaningful pullback. Historically, KOSPI has had more frequent and deeper drawdowns compared to DM markets. In addition, September and October generally exhibit the lowest returns from a seasonality perspective (Exhibit 8). Given this backdrop, it is an opportune time to assess the likelihood and magnitude of a regional correction. We introduce RADA R: Regional Asia Drawdown Risk model, which indicates that moderate drawdown probability has risen, although the probability of a severe drawdown is low. This supports a "buy the dip" approach in the event of a correction in regional equities which aligns with our positive strategic view. See more: Are markets too complacent? Introducing RADA R: Regional Asia Drawdown Risk model
Exhibit 1: 2nd Commercial Act amendment has been made for mandatory cumulative voting and expansion of election for audit committee members

AssessmentsKey policy agendas related to capital marketTimetableArticlesCurrentAmendments1st Commercial Act AmendmentExpansion of Board of Directors' fiduciary dutyCompany onlyBoth company and all shareholders3rd-July-2025Mandatory Electronic Shareholder MeetingsElectronic meetings held upon board resolutionElectronic meetings mandatoryStrengthening the "3% rule"3% voting cap applies only to internal directors when electing audit committee members3% voting cap applies to both internal and independent directors when electing audit committee members2nd Commercial Act AmendmentMandatory cumulative votingCumulative voting can be excluded via articles of incorporationCumulative voting cannot be excluded via articles of incorporation25th-Aug-2025Expansion of election for audit committee membersOne member elected2 or more members elected3rd Commercial Act AmendmentMandatory treasury share cancellationAllowing treasury shares post buybackMandatory cancellation of treasury shares post buybackNov-25Mandatory tender offer-The purchaser will be required to make a tender offer to acquire at least 50% + 1 share of the total issued shares of the target companyTax Incentives (In debate with potential adjustments)- For corporates with high payout ratios (&gt;40%) or with dividend increase by 5% YoY and 25% above payout ratio, separating the taxation of dividends (14%, 20%, 35% ranges)Dec-25
Yellow highlights show completed Commercial Act amendments so far Source: National Assembly, Various local media, compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 3: Key proposals have been concentrated around appointment of members of the board of directors

Exhibit 4: KOSPI has gained \(42\%\) , after plunging in April, without even a \(-5\%\) drawdown
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 5: KOSPI has had more frequent and deeper draw downs in history, while we note there has been hardly any drawdown over almost the past 5 months
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 6: Our new Regional Asian Drawdown Risk model for equity markets indicates that drawdown risk probability over a 12m horizon has increased to elevated levels across a moderate drawdown range of \(- 10\%\) and \(- 20\%\) , but the risk of a severe drawdown in excess of \(20\%\) remains low.

Exhibit 6: Our new Regional Asian Drawdown Risk model for equity markets indicates that drawdown risk probability over a 12m horizon has increased to elevated levels across a moderate drawdown range of \(-10\%\) and \(-20\%\) , but the risk of a severe drawdown in excess of \(20\%\) remains low.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 7: Our drawdown models predicting different ranges of drawdowns exhibit decent predictive power for corresponding drawdown risks

p views expressed in this research.
e research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/characteristics.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third-party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial products), data or offerings) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
